Keeping track of performance metrics shouldn't require navigating across multiple apps or digging into reports. With SAP‚Äôs KPI Cards on the Home Page, administrators can now offer end-users a personalized dashboard that pulls real-time data from various applications‚Äîright at their fingertips.

In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through how you, as an administrator, can create and configure KPI cards to help your users stay focused on what truly matters.

üéØWhy KPI Cards?

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) Cards give users a quick snapshot of essential metrics like sales Quotes  and opportunities. These cards are highly configurable and serve as visual indicators to drive data-informed decisions.

üîßPrerequisite: Enable the KPI Cards Feature

Before you start, make sure KPI Cards are enabled in your system.

Raise a case under the component CEC-CRM-PM-PF with the subject:"Enable Creation of KPI Cards" 

üß≠ Step-by-Step: Create Your KPI Cards

Once the feature is enabled, here‚Äôs how to set up KPI cards on your SAP Home Page:

entry.title: Bringing AI to SAP: Integrating Amazon Connect Q into Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
SAP Service Cloud offers seamless Computer Telephony Integration (CTI) capabilities, enabling agents to connect directly with contact center platforms like Amazon Connect. In this blog, we'll walk through the steps to configure the CTI adapter in SAP Service Cloud and validate the integration end-to-end.

 

Prerequisites: Amazon Connect Details Required from AWS Team

To successfully integrate Amazon Connect with SAP Service Cloud using the CTI adapter, please collect the following details from the AWS (Amazon Connect) team:

1. Amazon Connect CloudFront URL

  1. Example: https://d23xxxxxxx.cloudfront.net
  2. Purpose: Used in SAP CTI configuration as the Provider URL.
  3. This CloudFront distribution must be configured to host the CCP (Contact Control Panel) for Amazon Connect.

2. Agent Credentials (for Testing)

  1. AgentUserNameParam
  2. AgentPasswordParam
  3. These credentials are required to log in to the softphone widget within SAP Service Cloud.

3. Trusted Origin Domain (for SAP)

  1. SAP Service Cloud domain (e.g., myxxxxx.crm.ondemand.com) should be added as a trusted origin in the Amazon Connect instance settings.

4. Contact Flow Setup (Optional but Recommended)

  1. The contact flow configured to route incoming calls to the right agent queue.
  2. Helps simulate real call scenarios during testing.

5. User/Agent Setup Confirmation

  1. Confirm that the test agent is assigned to the correct routing profile and queue in Amazon Connect.
  2. This ensures the call is delivered properly to the agent via the embedded widget.

6. Call Recording and Transcript Configuration (Optional)

Ensure that call recording and transcript features are enabled in Amazon Connect to leverage the Phone Transcript Summary in SAP Service Cloud.

Step 1: Configure the CTI Adapter

  1. Log in to SAP Service Cloud.
  2. Click on the user icon (top-right corner) and select Settings.
  3. Navigate to All Settings ‚Üí CTI Configuration.
  4. Choose Amazon Connect as the communication provider.
  5. Enter the Amazon Connect CloudFront distribution URL (e.g., https://d23xxxxxxx.cloudfront.net) in the Provider URL field.

Step 2: Adjust Content Security Policies

To ensure the CloudFront domain is trusted by SAP Service Cloud:

  1. Go to Settings ‚Üí Content Security Policy Settings.
  2. Add the CloudFront domain (e.g., d23xxxxxxx.cloudfront.net) under all relevant sections to whitelist it.

Step 3: Validate the End-to-End Integration

  1. Log in to SAP Service Cloud.
  2. Click the CTI-Widget icon in the top-right corner.
  3. The Amazon Connect softphone should appear on the right panel, prompting you to log in.
  4. Enter the credentials (AgentUserNameParam and AgentPasswordParam) configured during the Amazon CDK deployment.
  5. After logging in, close the popup and refresh the page if needed.
  6. Set the agent status to Available in the softphone panel.

Step 4: Simulate an Incoming Call

  • Customer interacts with the website through the chatbot, the system automatically captures the engagement and logs it in the contact‚Äôs interaction history. This ensures a unified and comprehensive view of all customer touchpoints across channels.

  • The agent accepts incoming requests initiated by Chatbot and agent desktop will open automatically 

  • Interaction Between Agent and Customer

  • The agent's desktop will automatically save the transcript you can filter the interactions with chat 

  • When we click on the chat, it navigates to Amazon, where all chat interactions are stored, and an AI-generated summary is automatically created

 

Step 5: Complete the Call and Review Transcripts

  1. Once the call concludes, click Close Contact in the softphone panel.
  2. Refresh the timeline to view a new entry labeled Phone Transcript Summary (note: this may take a few minutes to appear).
  3. Click on the Phone Transcript entry to open a detailed view containing:
    • Call details and summary
    • Conversational analytics
    • Customer sentiment and talk time
    • Call recording
    • Full transcript with sentiment analysis

This configuration empowers customer service agents to efficiently handle calls directly within SAP Service Cloud, enhancing the customer experience with real-time insights and automation.

entry.title: Empowering SAP Service Cloud V2 with OpenText: Seamless Integration for Document Management
entry.content:
In today's digital-first customer service landscape, managing documents efficiently is crucial for ensuring speed, compliance, and seamless service delivery. SAP Service Cloud V2 now supports powerful integration with OpenText, enabling agents to securely manage, store, and retrieve customer documents within a single interface. This blog outlines the key steps to configure OpenText with SAP Service Cloud V2 and highlights how the integration streamlines customer interactions.

üìå Why OpenText + SAP Service Cloud V2?

The integration enables organizations to:

  • Centralize document storage and access directly within SAP.
  • Ensure compliance with data governance and retention policies.
  • Provide agents with a 360¬∞ view of customer interactions‚Äîincluding documents, cases, and correspondence.
  • Automate document capture, archiving, and retrieval processe

üîß Prerequisites: What You Need Before Integration

Before starting the configuration, ensure you have the following:

OpenText Extended Account Access

  • Administrator credentials to access the OpenText .
  • API and endpoint URLs.

SAP Service Cloud V2 Tenant Details

  • V2 instance with admin access.
  • Role-based authorization to manage integration settings.

OpenText Endpoint (Base URL) for Mashup

  • Example: https://contentserver.opentext.example.com
    Purpose: This acts as the destination for all document management operations.

Authentication Credentials (for Testing)

  • Username: <OpenTextUser>
  • Password: <OpenTextPassword>
    These credentials will be used to authenticate API calls from SAP to OpenText during testing and validation.

SAP Domain Whitelisting (Trusted Origin)

  • Your SAP Service Cloud domain must be added as a trusted origin within the OpenText configuration and vice versa. This ensures secure cross-origin communication between the two platforms.

Folder & Document Structure Setup (Recommended)

  • Predefine folder structures and metadata rules in OpenText to simulate realistic document storage scenarios during integration testing. This helps ensure documents are correctly categorized, archived, and retrieved within SAP Service Cloud V2.

Step 1: Configure the Open Text mashup 

  1. Log in to SAP Service Cloud.
  2. Click on the user icon (top-right corner) and select Settings.
  3. Navigate to All Settings ‚Üí Extensibility ‚Üí Mashup Authoring.
  4. Add the Mashup

Step 2: Adjust Content Security Policies

To ensure the CloudFront domain is trusted by SAP Service Cloud:

  1. Go to Settings ‚Üí Content Security Policy Settings.
  2. Add the CloudFront domain (e.g., opentext.com) under all relevant sections to whitelist it.

Step 3: Add Mashup in case the End-to-End Integration

  • Embed the OpenText mashup within the Case screen for easy access.
  • Seamlessly navigate to the OpenText Tab document in SAP Service Cloud.
  • Choose the appropriate communication channel for document storage or retrieval.

  • select the channel

  • Upon clicking the Submit button, the document is generated and added to the 'General ‚Üí Attachments' section

The reference document can be shared with the customer via the case email channel, allowing the process to continue seamlessly in alignment with the company's defined workflow

üìå Conclusion

Integrating OpenText with SAP Service Cloud V2 provides a unified digital workspace for agents‚Äîcombining customer data, case insights, and document management in one platform. This not only boosts operational efficiency but also strengthens compliance, transparency, and customer satisfaction.

If you're looking to enhance your SAP V2 experience, OpenText integration is a strategic step toward intelligent service management.

entry.title: Integrating Events from SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 into SAP BTP Event Mesh
entry.content:
The Event Mesh capability in SAP Integration Suite helps you manage your business events. You can publish and consume events across applications using Event Mesh

SAP Event Mesh supports event-driven architectures by enabling reliable communication between distributed applications using events and messaging queues. It decouples the sending and receiving applications, allowing for greater scalability, extensibility, and resilience.

In the context of SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2, Event Mesh can be used to subscribe to business object events ‚Äî such as a service ticket creation or sales quote update ‚Äî and route them to downstream consumers like SAP BTP services, third-party APIs, or AI-based microservices.

In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through the end-to-end steps to configure and integrate SAP Event Mesh with Sales and Service Cloud V2 using SAP BTP and CAP/CPI as middleware.

 

 

üõ†Prerequisites

Before you start, ensure:

  • Access to SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) with:
    • SAP Event Mesh service entitlement
    • SAP Integration Suite / CAP Runtime
  • Access to SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 (Autoflow) with proper admin permissions
  • Knowledge of:
    • Basics of Event Mesh
    • Handling OAuth tokens
    • Service Key consumption via REST/CPI/CAP

üß© Step 1: Create and Configure Event Mesh Instance

  1. Login to BTP Cockpit.
  2. Navigate to your Subaccount > Instances and Subscriptions.
  3. Click Create > Instance and choose:
    • Service: event-mesh
    • Plan: default

 

  1. Provide a name (e.g., event-mesh-salesv2) and click Create.
  2. After creation, go to the instance and create a service key. Note the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, tokenurl, messaging, etc.).

 

üîêStep 2: Create and Configure Messaging Queue & Topic

  1. Go to Event Mesh UI via the subscribed application tile.
  2. Go to Queues:
    • Create a new queue (e.g., salesv2/quotecreated)
  3. Go to Topics:
    • Add topic (e.g., salesv2/order/*)
  4. Bind it to the queue.

üîóStep 3: Enable Outbound Events in Sales and Service Cloud V2

  2. Create or update an Communication System .

  3. Under the Outbound Events tab or Autoflow:

entry.title: Empowering SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub: Multilingual Support for Service Cloud V2

In today‚Äôs global business landscape, offering multilingual support is crucial for reaching a broader audience. SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Translation Hub, in combination with SAP Build Apps, provides a powerful, no-code solution for automating translations in web and mobile applications. This blog demonstrates how you can create a translation feature‚Äîthat can be embedded in SAP Service Cloud V2 environments or used as a standalone application.

In this blog, we'll demonstrate how to:

  • Translate case data dynamically using SAP Translation Hub APIs.
  • Integrate this logic in a low-code/no-code app built with SAP Build Apps.
  • Embed the translation component directly into SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, or run it as a standalone app.

Prerequisite

  • SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2
  • SAP BTP Global Account with appropriate entitlements
  • SAP Build Apps subscription
  • Translation Hub service activation
  • Basic understanding of SAP integration patterns

The Business Scenario

Consider a typical service management case in an SAP environment where:

  • Service teams need to handle customer issues across different geographical regions
  • Customers submit cases in their native languages
  • Technical documentation and knowledge bases exist in multiple languages
  • Cross-functional teams require real-time translation capabilities for efficient collaboration

we can see how language barriers can impact service delivery when dealing with technical descriptions, customer communications, and knowledge base content.

entry.title: Unlocking Multilingual Document Translation with SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, we explored how to enable text translation within SAP Build Apps using SAP Translation Hub, making apps more inclusive and globally accessible.

Now, let‚Äôs take this a step further. What if you need to translate entire documents‚Äîlike Word files, PDFs, or HTML content? In this post, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to integrate SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub to create a document translation flow‚Äîquickly, efficiently, and without writing extensive code.

üìñStory: One Quote, Two Languages ‚Äî One Lost Deal?

Meet Alex, a sales manager at a global electronics company based in Germany. He‚Äôs chasing a big opportunity with a Japanese client. The quote is ready, the price is right ‚Äî but it‚Äôs in English. The client requests it in Japanese.

Alex scrambles. He asks a colleague for help. He copy-pastes parts of the quote into a translation tool. He worries about accuracy, especially with technical terms. Meanwhile, the competitor ‚Äî who sent a native-language quote ‚Äî wins the deal

Could this have been avoided? Absolutely.

Enter SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub ‚Äî a powerful no-code solution to translate sales quotes and documents instantly, either as a standalone tool or tightly integrated with SAP CX Sales Cloud.

üß∞ Prerequisites

To implement this solution, you‚Äôll need:

  • ‚úÖSAP BTP subaccount with access to:
    • SAP Build Apps
    • SAP Translation Hub (entitlement required)
  • ‚úÖSAP CX Sales Cloud (optional, for embedded use case)
  • ‚úÖDocument format: PDF, DOCX, or HTML
  • ‚úÖBTP Destination or integration layer (CAP / SAP Integration Suite)

üéØUse Case: Quote Translation in SAP Sales Cloud

Sales teams often generate quotes in their default language. However, sending proposals in a customer‚Äôs native language improves clarity, trust, and conversion rates.

Example:
A salesperson in Spain generates a quote in English and wants to send it to a client in Brazil. Using this solution, the salesperson uploads the quote, selects ‚ÄúPortuguese (Brazil)‚Äù as the target language, and receives a translated document ‚Äî within seconds.

The translated document is then sent directly to the customer or attached to the Sales Cloud opportunity.

üõ†Ô∏è How It Works

  1. Generate Quote (SAP CX Sales Cloud): Standard PDF/Word output from a quote process.
  2. Upload to SAP Build Apps: User uploads the file and selects target language.
  3. Translation via SAP Translation Hub: The file is translated via secure API calls.
  4. Return Translated File: File is returned as downloadable content or pushed back to SAP Sales Cloud in attachment Tab.

üîÑ Deployment Options: Standalone or Integrated

Option 1: Standalone App (No SAP CX Required)

  • A universal tool for business users across sales, legal, procurement, etc.
  • Upload any business document and get instant translations.
  • Deploy via SAP Build Apps and BTP ‚Äî no coding needed.
  • Useful even for companies not yet using SAP Sales Cloud.

Option 2: Embedded in SAP CX Sales Cloud

  • Add translation buttons directly in the Quote Object Page.
  • Automatically trigger translation after quote generation.
  • Store translated versions in the same quote  record.

entry.title: Have You Heard About Service Management Solutions from SAP?
entry.content:
How One Service Call Turned Into a Business Breakthrough

It started with a broken compressor on a hot summer day.

Anna, a service manager at an industrial equipment company, got the call: a key customer‚Äôs machine had failed‚Äîand production was at risk. The clock was ticking, and the pressure was on. In the past, resolving a case like this would have meant a flurry of phone calls, digging through disconnected systems for warranty info, manually checking technician availability, and hoping the right spare part was in stock.

But not this time.

Thanks to SAP‚Äôs end-to-end Service Management solution, Anna‚Äôs team had everything they needed in one place‚Äîfrom customer contract details and installed base info to intelligent technician scheduling, mobile field execution, and real-time updates. Within hours, the right technician was on-site with the correct spare part. The issue was fixed before it became a crisis.

entry.title: Convert SAP BTP Certificate Service Keys to PFX Files
entry.content:
SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) allows you to create service keys of type certificate. These certificates can be exported from BTP and imported into other systems as client certificates to securely call SAP BTP services using certificate-based authentication.

However, the BTP cockpit provides the certificate chain and the private key only in text form. While some systems may accept this format, others require the upload of a certificate file containing all these details in one piece. (In addition, since it carries the certificate's private key, this file should usually be encrypted.)

I recently set up the integration between SAP Sales/Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP Integration Suite/Cloud Integration, in which I had to convert the textual details from the service key into an encrypted PFX file.

While such tasks are often carried out with command-line tools, such as OpenSSL, where you need to remember all the correct commands, I was looking for an easy GUI-based approach. In this blog I want to explain how to create the PFX certificate with the free, multi-platform GUI tool KeyStore Explorer, which is very helpful for this task.

The process consists of three simple tasks:

  1. Create text files for the certificate chain and the key
  2. Import these files into KeyStore Explorer
  3. Save them as PFX file

 

1. Create Text Files

  1. Open the service key details in SAP BTP and switch to Form view.
  2. Certificate Chain:
    Copy the text from the certificate field into an empty text file and insert line breaks so that -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----, -----END CERTIFICATE----- and the actual certificate content (which is Base64 encoded) have separate lines. Save the file, for instance, as cert_chain.pem
    Please note that the content from the certificate field contains the whole certificate chain consisting of three certificates.
    The should look like this:

  3. Private Key:
    Copy the text from the key field into an empty text file and insert line breaks so that -----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----, -----END RSA PRIVATE KEY----- and the actual key content (which is Base64 encoded) have separate lines. Save the file, for instance, as key.pem

That's it for the preparation step.

 

2. Import Text Files

  1. Open KeyStore Explorer and create a new keystore with the type PKCS#12.

  2. Select the Import Key Pair button in the toolbar and choose OpenSSL as import type.‚ÄÉ

  3. In the import dialog, uncheck the Encrypted Private Key checkbox and provide the previously created files for the private key and the certificate file.

  4. You will be prompted for an alias for the keystore. You can simply accept the suggested one.‚ÄÉ

  5. Another dialog will appear that asks you to enter a New Key Pair Entry Password.
    Enter a strong password.
    My suggestion: Generate a password with a password manager to store it securely, and Copy&Paste it.
    We'll need this password again when saving the PFX file and later when importing it into the target system/tool.

 

With that, we have all the necessary details in the keystore and can view all the details of the imported files:

‚ÄÉ

 

3. Save PFX File

  1. With the full certificate chain and the private key imported into the key store, we can now save the keystore as PFX file.
    In this step, we have to enter a password again to protect the file (since it contains the secret private key).
    Use the same password as during the import. This password will also be needed when uploading the PFX file into a system/tool of your preference.
  2. In the last step, enter a filename for the PFX file, for instance client_cert_enc.pfx
    ‚ÄÉ

That's it! Now you can import the PFX file into the system/tool where you need it. For instance into the Communication System of an SAP Sales/Service Cloud Version 2 system:

I hope this blog is helpful!

entry.title: AI‚ÄëPowered Self‚ÄëService Portal with SAP Build Apps and SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Abstract

In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self‚Äëservice portal built with SAP Build Apps, seamlessly integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. End users submit a service request by uploading an image . The image is analyzed in AI Core to detect key objects or issues; the findings are then merged into the case description so agents start with rich context. We also run sentiment analysis on the user‚Äôs text, helping auto‚Äëprioritize and categorize the case. The result is an end‚Äëto‚Äëend, low‚Äëcode + AI workflow that reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and accelerates resolution time.

Use Case: Broken Home Appliance Service Request

Scenario:
A customer‚Äôs washing machine stops working and makes unusual noise. Instead of calling customer support, they log into the self-service portal built on SAP Build Apps.

What you‚Äôll build

A responsive self‚Äëservice portal where customers can:

  • Log in, fill a lightweight form, and upload a photo (e.g., broken product/utility issue).
  • See real‚Äëtime AI insights (objects detected; suspected issue) before submitting.
  • Submit a Service Request (Case) to Service Cloud V2, with AI context appended to the description and sentiment tag auto‚Äëset.

Agents in Service Cloud V2 will see a richer ticket with:

  • Customer text + image URL/attachment.
  • AI object/issue summary and confidence scores.
  • Sentiment label (Positive/Neutral/Negative) for quick triage.

Solution Overview

The solution leverages three modern SAP technologies:

  • SAP Build Apps: Low-code environment for building web/mobile self-service portals.
  • SAP BTP Destination: Secure connection layer to backend SAP services.
  • SAP Service Cloud V2: Manages and tracks customer service cases.
  • SAP AI Core: Automates image analysis and sentiment analysis to enhance ticket information

The workflow (as visualized below) demonstrates how these layers interact:

  • End-to-End Ticket Automation: Instantly raise service requests by uploading an image.
  • AI-Powered Image Analysis: Automatic detection of objects or issues in uploaded images via SAP AI Core.
  • Auto-Enriched Ticket Descriptions: AI writes relevant context and details.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes customer descriptions for emotion and urgency for better case triaging.

Reference architecture

 

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have the following in place:

SAP BTP Account with access to:

  • SAP Build Apps service
  • SAP AI Core service
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 tenant

Service Keys and Destinations:

  • Properly configured SAP BTP Destination for Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core

AI Models Deployed:

  • Object Detection model ( in SAP AI Core)
  • Sentiment Analysis model
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP, Destinations, and Service Cloud concepts

Step‚Äëby‚Äëstep build guide

1.Prepare Your AI Services in SAP AI Core

  • Deploy or onboard your image recognition and sentiment analysis models to SAP AI Core.
  • Expose these models through RESTful endpoints.

2. Configure Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit

Create destinations for:

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 API
  • SAP AI Core inference endpoints
  • Set appropriate authentication methods (OAuth2, Basic, etc.).

3.Build the Self-Service Portal with SAP Build Apps

  • Use SAP Build Apps‚Äô drag-and-drop interface to design a user-friendly portal.
  • Add functionality for:
    • User authentication
    • Image upload
    • Input fields for additional ticket information
  • Configure data resources to connect to SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core via the BTP destinations.

Build the portal in SAP Build Apps

Step 1: Create an SAP Build Apps portal tailored to your requirements.

Step 2: Implement logic to process the uploaded image using SAP AI Core. Extract the description from the image and perform sentiment analysis on the extracted text. Based on the description and sentiment, automatically update the subject line and categorize the case accordingly.

Step 3: Invoke the Service Cloud V2 API to create a case along with the attachment.

Video

 

Summary

This approach shows how you can build a pure destination‚Äëdriven integration between Build Apps, AI Core, and Service Cloud V2. By leveraging SAP BTP Destinations, you eliminate the need for custom middleware, keep the architecture lightweight, and still enable AI‚Äëpowered case creation with images, sentiment, and prioritization.

entry.title: Case Management: Preconditions in Case Flow Steps
entry.content:
Prerequisite:

A draft case type version.

Introduction:

Preconditions in case flow steps define the rules that determine when a step can be performed. By configuring preconditions, administrators gain fine-grained control over the flow execution, ensuring that certain steps become actionable only when the specified conditions are met.

As the name suggests, a precondition is a requirement that must be satisfied before a step can be acted upon. During case updates or when the case flow is updated, these conditions are continuously evaluated until they are fulfilled for the steps of the current phase. Once a precondition is satisfied and the step is enabled for action, it remains valid, meaning the system will not re-check it to disable the step later, even if the condition is no longer satisfied.

This mechanism ensures that business processes remain consistent, predictable, and aligned with organizational rules, while also offering administrators the flexibility to design intelligent and conditional workflows.

Examples:

The following examples highlight a few possible use cases of case flows with preconditions, showing how they help streamline processes, enforce business rules, and enhance efficiency in case management:

1) Triggering Feedback Loop:

Consider a customer support case where an organization wants to capture customer satisfaction after case completion. A precondition can be configured such that the ‚ÄúTrigger Feedback Survey‚Äù step can be executed only if the case is completed and for certain customer interaction channel. Once the conditions are satisfied, the feedback flow is actionable. This ensures feedback is collected only from genuine resolved cases, avoids sending irrelevant surveys, and improves both customer experience and the quality of insights gathered.

2) Approval in Refund Cases:

In a customer refund case, an approval step may be required before processing. A precondition can be configured so that the ‚ÄúManager Approval‚Äù step to be enabled only if the refund amount exceeds certain amount or the customer is flagged as high-risk. This ensures that standard refunds are processed quickly without delays, while large or sensitive refunds go through additional oversight, balancing both efficiency and control.

3) Creating Service Order:

In a field service request case, a technician may need to be dispatched to resolve a customer issue. A precondition can be configured so that the ‚ÄúCreate Service Order‚Äù step is triggered only if the case type is ‚ÄúService Request‚Äù, the case category is ‚ÄúTechnical Issue‚Äù, and required details (diagnostics, address, and contact information) are available. This ensures that service orders are created only for valid service-related cases, avoiding unnecessary technician dispatch for billing or inquiry cases, thereby improving operational efficiency and resource utilization.

Configuration:

The steps below demonstrate how to configure a precondition for a To-Do step, and the same steps can be applied to all step types.

1. Open a draft case type version in detail view

 2. Navigate to Case Flow tab

3. Click on Create Step button which shows the list of step types that can be created.

 4. You can choose any step type to add a precondition. In this example, we‚Äôll configure the preconditions for a To-Do step.

5. Fill in all the required fields in the step creation form, then click the Create Preconditions button in the Pre-conditions section. 

 6. A modal popup appears, allowing you to add preconditions based on Case entity attributes.

 7. Click the first dropdown to select a Case entity attribute, then add a condition based on that attribute. In this example, let‚Äôs select Status. The dropdown also includes any extension fields created for the Case entity.

8. The second dropdown displays the possible operators based on the selected Case entity attribute. In this example, let's select Equal operator.

 9. The last input box allows the user to enter a value for the selected Case entity attribute. In this example, let's select In Process status.

 10. Click the plus (+) button to add another condition within the same condition group.

 11. Select one of the two options: ANY or ALL. If you select ANY, the condition group is considered true if at least one condition within it is true. If you select ALL, all conditions must be satisfied for the condition group to be true.

 12. To add a new condition group, click the New Condition Group button.

 13. Between condition groups, you can choose the condition operator AND or OR. If you select AND, the entire condition is true only when all condition groups are true. If you select OR, the entire condition is true if any one of the condition groups is true.

14. Once the conditions are configured, click the Save button to save the preconditions.

In this example, we have configured the following condition: the To-Do step will be enabled for processing only when the status code is In Process and the case is created for a priority customer, or when the case is escalated.

15. The configured precondition is displayed in the Pre-conditions section, where it can be edited or deleted.

 16. Click on Create button to create the step.

 17. Finally, activate the draft case type version. The case type is ready, allowing you to create a case where you can observe the effect of the preconditions.

Preconditions in Action for Different Step Types:

The case type used for this example is Preconditions in Case Flow Step (ZPCS)

To-Do Step:

Step name: Collect Customer Data

Precondition configured: The To-Do step will be enabled for processing only when the status code is In Process and the case is created for a priority customer, or when the case is escalated.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and the Set Step to Done button, which completes the step, is disabled.

Satisfy the precondition by either escalating the case or changing the status to In Process and marking the priority customer flag as true. In this example, we will escalate the case. Once the precondition is satisfied, the step is enabled for processing, allowing the agent to mark it as complete by clicking the Set Step to Done button.

De-escalate the case to make the precondition unsatisfied; the step will still remain processable. Preconditions act as entry conditions.

Input Step:

Step name: Collect Data

Precondition configured: The Input step will be enabled for processing only when the status of the case is In Process.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and both the Set Step to Done button (which completes the step) and the Save button (which saves the input step form) are disabled. The entire form is also disabled, preventing agents from entering any values.

Satisfy the precondition by updating the status to In Process. Once the precondition is met, the entire form is enabled for the agent to enter values, and the Set Step to Done button becomes active. After the agent fills in the form, the Save button is also enabled. Even if the precondition becomes unsatisfied later, the step remains processable.

Approval Step:

Step name: Refund Approval

Precondition configured: The approval process will be enabled when the refund amount exceeds 5000$

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and Submit Approval Request button is disabled. 

The approval step gets enabled if the refund amount exceeds 5000$. Even if the precondition becomes unsatisfied later, the step remains processable.

Feedback Step:

Step name: Request Feedback

Precondition configured: The Feedback step will be enabled, allowing it to be sent to the reporter of the case once the case is completed. 

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Feedback step is designed to send automatically once the current phase is completed, provided its preconditions are satisfied; therefore, no buttons specific to the Feedback step will be shown.

Satisfy the precondition by changing the status to Completed. The Feedback step is now enabled to be sent automatically when the current phase is completed.

The Feedback step can also be configured to be manually triggered by the agent once the precondition is met. In the example below, since the precondition is not satisfied (same precondition configured - feedback request can be send once the case is completed), the Submit button remains disabled. 

Satisfy the precondition by changing the status to Completed. The Feedback step is now enabled to be sent manually by clicking Submit button.

Action Step:

Step name: Create Service Order

Precondition configured: Automatically create a service order if repair is required.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Action step is executed automatically once the precondition is met, without any agent intervention; hence, no button is displayed for this step.

Once the precondition is satisfied by setting the ‚ÄòRequires Repair‚Äô flag to true, the service order is created automatically.

If no precondition is configured for the Action step, it executes automatically as soon as the phase containing the step changes to In Progress.

The Actions step allows admins to configure a step that performs actions such as creating a Task, Opportunity, Service Order, Sub-Case, Sales Quote, Lead or calling an external hook automatically.

Assignment Step:

Step name: Set the ‚ÄòRequires Repair‚Äô flag

Precondition configured: Set the ‚ÄòRequires Repair‚Äô flag when the case is created as a service request.

 Assignment action configured: Set the ‚ÄòRequires Repair‚Äô flag

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Assignment step is executed automatically once the precondition is met, without any agent intervention; hence, no button is displayed for this step.

Once the precondition is satisfied by updating the subject to include 'SERVICE_REQUEST', the Assignment step executes and updates the case.

The Assignment step allows admins to configure a step to modify case property values. The properties to be updated are added as assignment actions, as shown below.

If no precondition is configured for the Assignment step, it executes automatically as soon as the phase containing the step changes to In Progress.

All step types can be executed even without preconditions; configuring a precondition is optional.

Conclusion:

Preconditions in case flow steps provide a flexible and powerful way to control the execution of steps within a case. They act as entry conditions, ensuring that each step becomes actionable only when the specified criteria are met. This allows organizations to enforce business rules, streamline processes, and maintain consistency while offering administrators the ability to design intelligent, conditional workflows.

While preconditions enhance control, all step types‚Äîincluding To-Do, Input, Approval, Feedback, Action, and Assignment steps‚Äîcan still execute without them, making precondition configuration optional. By strategically leveraging preconditions, organizations can improve operational efficiency, reduce errors, and ensure that steps are triggered only when appropriate, without requiring unnecessary agent intervention.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud V2 Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
What is new in SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud version 2?  

Explore a selection of our new features in this blog post and join our webcasts for live demos and comprehensive insights into SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP Service Cloud V2 updates. 

Register for our Q3 2025 customer webcasts  

October 14 webcast 
SAP Service Cloud Version 2, Utilities and SAP Enterprise Service Management: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

October 16 webcast 
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, Sales and Foundation topics: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

Join us at SAP Connect
Please also join us at the upcoming Customer Experience Connect where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey. 
Learn more about the SAP CX portfolio here.

What is new in SAP Sales Cloud‚ÄØV2 

SAP Sales Cloud development continues to focus on enhancing key features and workspaces, embedded AI and generative AI, and improving lead-to-cash process automation. We have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual tasks that traditionally arise between SFA and ERP processes. Our pace of innovation continues to accelerate, but customer feedback remains a critical aspect of our development. Here are a few of our release improvements that stem from customer requests and feedback.  

UI extensibility and mashup permissions  
Customer engagement can be nuanced and may require greater flexibility to meet ideal customer use cases. To support this, administrators now have greater flexibility configuring workspaces and using mashups to provide access for microphone, notifications, and clipboard. This allows for more seamless engagement and supports situations where use of voice commands or notification loop up is helpful, in addition to improving read/write from and to the system‚Äôs clipboard. 

Generative AI Contact and Individual Customer Duplicate Checks 
Maintaining clean and accurate sales data and records are critical for effective sales organizations but duplicate and redundant data remains a plague. Existing SAP Sales Cloud data quality tools do a great job cleansing and harmonizing data, but in situations where there are not exact matches or several spellings some users reported missed matches. The new generative AI duplicate check option throws a larger data analysis net and provides users with actionable results paired with AI driven confidence scores. This allows users to take appropriate action or drill down, ensuring that they can make informed decisions faster.  

Restriction rules for email templates 
Generative email creation linked with templates and user driven email templates can dramatically increase email outreach and response times, but for organizations with several organizational units and geographic locations the number of available options can become confusing for the end user. Now administrators can maintain restriction rules for templates, ensuring users only have access to the right subset of templates. This allows administrators the ability to refine by organizational unit and user role, helping end users quickly choose the right template for their customer engagement needs.  

 Field Query Configuration Improvements and UI Enhancement 

To improve usability and administrator experience, we have added a new tab for configuring field query attributes. Within ‚ÄòExtensibility Administration‚Äô, users can now sort, filter, and search for relevant attributes. The workspace provides a detailed breakdown and a ‚ÄòShow Limits‚Äô toggle. We plan to continue to enhance both extensibility and the ease of use for extensibility administration.  

What is new in SAP Service Cloud  

In SAP Service Cloud, we have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual workloads, expedite issue resolution, and enhance the overall agent experience. In our upcoming webcast, we will showcase these innovations, along with a range of other advanced capabilities, illustrating how they can streamline operations and elevate customer service.  

Improve case categorization with Business Information Extraction in Cases

 In the previous webcast we introduced Business Information Extraction, an AI feature that enables you to automatically extract key information like product names and serial IDs from customer emails. Now we have expanded the use of Business Information Extraction to Cases and you can use the extracted data to automatically categorize cases for faster and more efficient handling 

Business Information Extraction in Cases 
 

Gain improved insights with enhanced interaction and resolution summaries (machine learning)   
There are new machine learning scenarios designed to enhance interaction and resolution summaries. Sentiment Trends and Sentiment Graph add insights to the interaction summary, allowing service agents to better understand the tone of the customer interactions. You can also add internal and external case notes which are used the AI-generated resolution summary to create a more detailed overview. 

Expedite issue to resolution with the direct integration with SAP Field Service Management  
The new direct integration with SAP Field Service Management simplifies the end-to-end service delivery from the very first customer contact all the way to onsite repair. With a smooth integration between contact center and field service you can shorten resolution time and fix the issue on the first visit.   
 

Utilities customer service: gain improved insights with external alerts and quick view for meters 
For utilities contact centers, we have added new features that bring important insights for customer service agents: 

  • External Alerts: You can now add external alerts to the premise and contract views. These alerts are created in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Quick View for Meters: In the services or premise tab, you can quickly view all the details of a meter, including the device's location and device location notes. 

Create outbound letters quickly with the OpenText Document Presentment Service integration 
The integration enables agents to quickly create outbound letters using automatically prepopulated fields and brand-aligned templates. This feature allows for the swift creation of professional PDFs, which can be sent as email attachments to customers.


 

Creating outbound letters 

 

More information

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 What‚Äôs New 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 What‚Äôs New 
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 Release Navigator single access point to release content 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 Release Navigator 

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Data Transfer Tool
entry.content:
With the launch of SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2, a common question arises ‚Äî how do we migrate data from V1 to V2?
SAP addresses this with the Data Transfer Tool, designed to handle standard object data and basic configurations.
Curious to know how it works? Let‚Äôs explore!

Data Transfer Tool

The Data Transfer tool helps transfer object-wise business data and configurations from V1 to V2.
The following scenarios are supported by the Data Transfer tool:

  • Single and Phased Go-Live implementations: 
    The tool facilitates both single and phased go-live approaches, allowing organizations to transition data in stages or all at once, depending on their implementation strategy.
  • Data and Configurations Transfer: It supports the transfer of both data and configuration settings, ensuring that necessary information and system settings are migrated appropriately.
  • Extension fields, Notes, and Attachments: These are supported for transition when mapping is completed by business objects. The scope would vary for different business objects.

How to get access to this feature?

Create a case including your V2 tenant details using the component LOD-LE-MIG-CNS.

Pre-requisites for Data Transfer

  • V2 system should be in an empty state, with no business data or configurations. Few configurations for Cases, Custom Party etc. should be manually created in V2, prior to the data transfer.
  • All prerequisites associated with each object must be fulfilled before proceeding.

Supported Objects

  • Organizational Units
  • Business Partners
  • Business Partner Relationships
  • Identities
  • Sales Territory
  • Product Category Hierarchies
  • Materials
  • Competitor Products
  • Installation Point/Registered Product
  • Registered Product
  • Installed Base
  • Warranty
  • Activities ‚Äì Appointments, Chats, Emails, Phone Calls, Tasks
  • Opportunities
  • Leads
  • Sales Quotes
  • Tickets
  • Communication Systems

**The objects mentioned in this blog reflect the current scope. These may evolve with future SAP updates and enhancements.

General Steps:

  1. Log in to the V1 system using your administrator credentials.
  2. Navigate to:Transition ‚Üí Data Transfer.
  3. Select the required business object from the list.
    Upon selection, the custom extension fields for the object will appear in a separate section at the bottom. Standard fields are automatically included in the data transfer once the object is selected.
  4. Under the Extension Fields tab, enable the checkboxes under the Transfer column for each custom field you wish to include in the data transfer.
  5. (Optional) Perform a Test Data Transfer:
    1. Click Test Data Transfer.
    2. Provide a specific object ID or leave it blank to allow the system to select one at random.
      1.  By default, data for one instance is transferred, including extension fields, business configurations, and code lists.
      2.  To transfer only data, enable the Transfer Only Data switch.
    3. Click OK.
      1.  The selected object‚Äôs settings, configurations, and KUT fields will remain available in the V2 system after test transfer.
  6. To perform the actual data transfer:
    1. Click Transfer Data.
    2. Confirm the action by selecting Yes.
      Once the initial transfer is completed, delta transfer mode is enabled.
      Any updates to the object in V1 will be automatically transferred to V2.
      Note: Updates to settings and configurations are not included in delta transfers and must be manually re-configured in V2.
      The ‚ÄúFinished‚Äù status in the Send Status column indicates that the transfer from V1 is complete. This does not confirm receipt in V2.
      Delta Mode will remain active until Stop Delta is selected. While active, object data updates are transferred automatically - excluding settings and configurations.
      Verify transfer consistency by comparing the values in the Sending Instances and Received Instances columns.
      While these numbers may not be identical (due to filter logic or count variations between systems), they should be reasonably close.
      If you still notice discrepancies, it‚Äôs likely due to differences in how objects are migrated based on their status and other factors. We will cover it in the section 'Object-Wise Details'.
  7. Log in to the V2 system and confirm that the data has been successfully transferred.
    Entities not included in the transfer will appear with empty details.
  8. Initiate Post-Processing:
    Once all transfers are complete, select Start Post-Processing to notify relevant services and begin post-processing activities in the target system.

Data Transfer and Monitoring Options

Data Transfer Tool

Below table explains the various data transfer options available in the Data Transfer Tool:

Option

Purpose

Test Data Transfer

Sends one instance of the object, including the extension fields, business configurations, and code lists. If Transfer Only Data switch is enabled, it excludes the extension fields, business configurations, and code lists of the selected instance.

Transfer Data

Sends all data, including the extension fields, business configurations, and code lists. If a business object‚Äôs status shows Error Occurred, clicking the Transfer Data button again will reprocess only the data packages that encountered errors during the previous transfer.

Stop Delta

Stops automatically sending any new or changed data after the initial load, and applies to all transferred objects.

Start Post-Processing

Starts the final processing for transferred objects after the initial data load, linking related records, updating searches, and activating configurations in the target system.

Extension Fields

Lists the extension fields that are supported for transfer.

Transfer Extension Field Definition

Transfers metadata of the selected extension fields.

Transfer History

Lists the details of multiple transfers initiated by a user.

The following table shows the various monitoring options available in the Data Transfer Tool:

Option

Purpose

Objects

Lists all supported objects.

More Information

Lists object specific documentation links.

Existing Instances

This figure is calculated every night via a job from Readiness Check, i.e. if someone adds new data during the day, it will not be covered

Sending Instances

This represents the number of instances sent to V2. However, it may not match the ‚ÄúExisting Instances‚Äù count because the application applies certain filters before sending to V2. Additionally, not all of these instances may be processed by the application mapper, leading to a mismatch in counts.

Error Sending Instances

This usually means, that the payload for the instance was too big to be sent (e.g. a sales order with thousands of items).

Received Instances

This is the count on V2 side, regardless, if the instances were created via Data Transfer or manually created in V2.

Send Status

It shows the outcome of starting the data transfer process, for example Finished (initiation succeeded) or Error Occurred (initiation failed). This only reflects whether the transfer request was successfully triggered, not whether the data has fully moved from V1 to V2.

Delta Mode

It indicates if automatic updates (delta transfers) are active for a business object after its initial data load. If delta transfers are stopped or need to be restarted for a specific object, it can be done by performing a full load for that object using the Transfer Data button. A green diamond icon indicates that Delta Mode is active for the object. A blank/white diamond icon means Delta Mode is inactive, typically because the initial/full load has not yet been run for that object.

Target Tenant

Lists the target tenant details with the direct link to open them.

Object-Wise Details:

It is recommended to follow the below sequence while transferring the objects.

1. Organizational Units

Points to Note:

  • Marketing Units and Reporting Line Unit functions are not transferred. The Org Unit will get created, but without these functions.
  • Org Unit with only Plant function will be moved into the Plant entity in V2
  • Org Unit with Plant and other functions will be transferred to both Plant and Organizational Unit.
  • Reporting line roles are not automatically transferred and must be manually assigned in V2 later.

2. Business Partners

Points to Note:

  • The Business Partners included in the transition are:
    1. Account
    2. Individual Customers
    3. Contacts
    4. Employees
    5. Competitors
    6. Partners
    7. Partner Contacts
  • Only the extension fields from Business Partner- Common node is supported
  • The number of instances transferred to V2 may not match the count in V1 due to differences in counting logic between the two systems.

3. Business Partner Relationships

Points to Note:

  • Supports the following:
    1. Standard relationship roles (Account-Contact, Employee Responsible)
    2. Custom-defined relationship roles with codes up to 6 characters, provided the corresponding Y-coded values are preconfigured in V2 (i.e., Z-codes in the source system must be created as Y-codes in V2).
    3. Sales area‚Äìdependent relationships (e.g., Partner Functions)
    4. Account team relationships (e.g., current Employee Responsible)
  • Business Partners should be transferred already
  • The number of instances transferred to V2 may not match the count in V1 due to differences in counting logic between the two systems.

4. Identities

Points to Note:

  • Transfers all Business Users and SAP Support Users, along with their user settings (credentials, status, user preferences, etc.) from V1 to V2.
  • Security Policy will not be transferred.
  • Data can be validated in V2 from ‚ÄòAll Settings‚Äô ‚Üí ‚ÄòUsers and Control‚Äô ‚Üí ‚ÄòUsers‚Äô.

5. Sales Territory

Points to Note:

  • Transition includes standard and extension fields from Root node.
  • The connected business objects (Accounts, Employee, Business Partner Relationships, Sales Quotes and Opportunities) should be transitioned successfully either before or after the transition of Sales Territory.
  • Manually maintain the territory rules in V2 later. The ‚ÄòDerive Territory‚Äô action in V2 works only if territory rules are already maintained in V2. If there are no rules maintained, the territory assignments for a transitioned account are deleted while running the derive territory action.

6. Product Category Hierarchies

Points to Note:

  • Product Categories in V1 are referred to as Product Groups in V2.
  • In V2, the concept of Root node is not used. So, the immediate children of the Root becomes the top-level Product Groups
  • ‚ÄòProduct Assignment Allowed‚Äô feature in V1 is not supported in V2.

7. Materials

Points to Note:

  • Extension fields in COMMON and SALES_PROCESS_INFO nodes are supported.
  • All External IDs of a Product can be viewed under Product Details ‚Üí General tab ‚Üí External IDs for Integration
  • Only UoMs with ‚ÄòReleased‚Äô or ‚ÄòIn Preparation‚Äô status are transferred. The ‚ÄòBlocked‚Äô status will not be transferred.

8. Competitor Products

Points to Note:

  • Materials business object must be transitioned before transitioning Competitor Products.
  • Only the extension fields in the COMPETITOR_INFORMATION node of Materials is supported.

9. Installation Point/Registered Product

Points to Note:

  • Installation Point of type Text in V1 will be transitioned as Functional Location in V2
  • Adoption to supports access level restrictions (ACL), Extensions and Attachments are not supported.

10. Registered Product

Points to Note:

  • For transitioning Registered Products from V1 to V2, trigger transition of Registered Product and Installation Point/Registered Product in V1
  • Adoption to supports access level restrictions (ACL), Extensions and Attachments are not supported

11. Installed Base

Points to Note:

  • Extensions are not supported

12. Warranty

Points to Note:

  • Warranty description and duration is supported.

13. Activities

Points to Note:

  • The Data Transition Tool supports the transfer of individual activity types (such as tasks or appointments), but not the overall Activities business object.

a. Appointments

Points to Note:

  • Custom document type is not supported in V2.
  • Involved Parties, Campaigns, Activity Lists are not supported.
  • Only appointments and follow-up opportunities are transitioned for related documents.

b. Chats

Points to Note:

  • The transition of attachments (within a chat) is not supported. However, these attachments can be imported using OData APIs.

c. Emails

Points to Note:

  • Email templates and email channels are not transitioned.
  • The MIME types used to create the email attachments in SAP V1 must be configured and allowed in V2.
  • Except for the inline images added as URLs, all the other inline images are transitioned from SAP Cloud for Customer to SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 as attachments to the email instead of displaying in the email body.
  • The inline images added as URLs would only come up if the corresponding domains are added to the image source under content security policy (CSP). To manage CSP, navigate to User Menu  ‚Üí  Settings  ‚Üí All Settings  ‚Üí System Preferences  ‚Üí Content Security Policy.

d. Phone Calls

Points to Note:

  • All phone calls in ‚ÄòCompleted‚Äô status will be transferred to V2.
  • Outbound Phone calls in ‚ÄòCanceled‚Äô, ‚ÄòOpen‚Äô, ‚ÄòIn Progress‚Äô statuses will be transitioned to V2 as Appointments.
  • Inbound Phone calls in ‚ÄòCanceled‚Äô status will not be transitioned to V2.
  • Inbound Phone Calls in ‚ÄòOpen‚Äô and ‚ÄòIn Progress‚Äô statuses will be transitioned to V2 as ‚ÄòComplete‚Äô
  • Outbound Phone Calls in ‚ÄòOpen‚Äô and ‚ÄòIn Progress‚Äô statuses will be transitioned to V2 as Appointments
  • Any other statuses are not considered for transition
  • Transition of attachments (within a phone call) is not supported. However, attachments can be imported using OData APIs.

e. Tasks

Points to Note:

  • Extension fields are not supported.

14. Opportunities

Points to Note:

  • Extension fields, Attachments, Notes, Approval Information, Competitor and Competitor Products, Employee-based roles in sales teams, Territories, Related Objects etc. are supported.
  • The following Involved Parties are supported:
    • Ship-To
    • Bill-To
    • Payer
    • Partner
    • Partner Contact
  • After migrating opportunities from V1 to V2, the following configuration must be completed in V2:
    • Party Processing Data must be manually maintained under Settings√† Opportunities √† Party Schema. Party Roles will not be visible in the opportunities unless this is completed
    • Define the next Opportunity ID for creation of new opportunity in V2 by navigating to Settings √† Opportunities √† Number Range

15.  Leads

Points to Note:

  • Recommended to transition the Related Objects referenced by Leads (Opportunities, Activities) before initiating the transition of Leads.
  • Only the extension fields at the Root node are supported for transition.
  • Prospects/Accounts/Individual Customer/Contacts with address, Owner, Sales Employees, Sales Unit, Product Items, Notes (except Approval Notes) and Related Objects (with restrictions) are supported for transition.
  • Attachments and Access Control Data are not supported.

16.  Sales Quotes

Points to Note:

  • Sales quotes transitioned from SAP Cloud for Customer to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is displayed in read-only mode only and can't be edited.
  • Item Involved Parties, Item notes and attachments, Detail Pricing Information and Document Address are not supported for transition.

17.  Tickets

Points to Note:

  • Tickets are transitioned as Cases in V2.
  • The following configuration should be completed in V2 before transition:
    • Map the Status Dictionary to the Status Schema.
    • Set up the Case Type with the Party Schema and Status Mapping in Service Cloud Version 2.
    • Map the Ticket Type in V1 to the Case Type in V2 by navigating to Navigation Menu ‚Üí Transition ‚Üí Data Transfer (Phased) ‚Üí Document Type Mapping (in V1)
    • Transition the Status and Status Schema configuration objects before transitioning the Tickets object.
  • Internal memo is not supported for transition.
  • Custom Party Roles in the Involved Parties are not supported.
  • Attachments, Tasks, SLA milestones, Related Documents and Service Reference Objects and Extension fields at Root level are supported for transition.
  • Ticket Description will be transitioned as Case Description.
  • Ticket Notes (Internal Comment) will be transitioned to the default note type S000 in Case.

18. Communication Systems

Points to Note:

  • System ID, System Display ID, Host, Status and Created/Changed On and Created/Changed By data are supported for transition.
  • Status of the communication systems would be ‚ÄòInactive‚Äô in V2 after the transition.
  • Any authentication related attributes like Certificates, Users and Passwords are not supported for transition.
  • Systems linked to multiple business systems cannot be fully migrated. In such cases, only the first linked business system will be transferred, and any additional business systems must be set up manually in V2 after migration.

General Points:

  1. Extension fields supported via the Data Transfer Tool is limited to 150 at root level, and 30 for non-root entities. Not all data types are supported. Refer to the section 'Extension Fields' for more details.

  3. Extension scenarios are not supported for transition. It must be manually configured in V2.
  4. Fields of type code with values less than 70 in V1 will be created as static code lists.
  5. Fields of type code with values greater than 70 in V1 will be created as custom code lists in V2. These can be accessed from Settings -> All Settings -> Custom Code Lists. All the custom code lists are created with proxy name in V2 (for example, ExtDFE8DF5129E41FD0889F5E7AE0A0ED2D).
  6. Adaptation Changes, Analytical Content, Mashups, Language Adaptations will not be transitioned.
  7. Transition of Code List Restrictions is not supported and hence should be maintained manually in V2.
  8. The Key Metrics available under Accounts in V2 would reflect only the last 3 months (90 days) data for the activities.
  9. The counts (Existing/Sending/Received Instances) in Data Transfer tool, can only serve as an approximation.

entry.title: AI-Powered Dispute Management with SAP Enterprise Service Management (ESM) and S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced business environment, handling customer invoice disputes efficiently is critical to maintaining trust and improving financial operations. SAP Enterprise Service Management (ESM), when integrated with FI-AR Dispute Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, brings automation, AI, and seamless connectivity to streamline the entire process.

What is SAP S/4HANA Dispute Management?

Dispute Management is a subcomponent of SAP S/4HANA Financial Supply Chain Management (FSCM). It enables businesses to record, monitor, and resolve disputes related to customer invoices. With features such as workflow-driven case management, audit trails, and integration to accounts receivable, it ensures that every dispute is handled systematically and efficiently.

Key benefits include:

  • Centralized tracking of disputes
  • Improved collaboration between finance, sales, and customer service teams
  • Automated workflows for faster approvals and escalations
  • Enhanced reporting for dispute trends and root cause analysis

Role of Enterprise Service Management (ESM)

While SAP manages financial disputes effectively, many organizations struggle with cross-functional coordination. That‚Äôs where ESM comes in. ESM extends the principles of IT Service Management (ITSM) into business domains like Finance, HR, Procurement, and Customer Service.

By integrating SAP Dispute Management with an ESM platform (such as ServiceNow or SAP‚Äôs own service management tools), organizations gain:

  • Unified Service Portal: Customers, sales teams, and service agents can log, track, and monitor disputes through a single interface.
  • Automated Ticketing & Routing: Disputes raised in ESM automatically create dispute cases in SAP S/4HANA, ensuring seamless data flow.
  • Real-Time Updates: Resolution progress is synchronized between SAP and the ESM tool, reducing the need for manual follow-ups.

Quick summary of the flow

  • Customer sends email
  • ESM (case management) auto-creates a case
  • AI/OCR extracts invoice number, disputed amount, reason, attachments
  • Validate / enrich by looking up open receivables in S/4HANA
  • Create a formal Dispute record in S/4HANA (tie back to the ESM case)
  • Track, collaborate, resolve and close (sync statuses both ways)

Prerequisites

To enable this end-to-end process, organizations require:

  • An SAP S/4HANA system with FI-AR Dispute Management
  • An Enterprise Service Management platform (e.g., SAP ESM or ServiceNow)
  • A middleware/integration layer such as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI)
  • Document extraction capabilities for AI/OCR-based data capture

End-to-End Process Flow

The integrated dispute process can be summarized in six steps (as shown in the flow):

 

 

 

1. Customer raises a dispute via email
A customer initiates contact by sending an email to the company‚Äôs shared dispute mailbox (e.g., disputes@company.com). The email may highlight issues such as overcharges, incorrect quantities, or pricing discrepancies and typically includes details like the invoice number, disputed amount, and reason for the dispute.

2. Case Creation

Once the email is received, SAP Enterprise Service Management automatically creates a case and assigns it to the appropriate case type. The system can also categorize the case and route it to the right support team without manual intervention.

3. Information Extraction

Artificial intelligence extracts key details from the email‚Äîsuch as invoice number, disputed amount, and reason for dispute‚Äîconverting unstructured text into structured business information that can be used downstream.

4. Lookup Receivable Items

The system then connects to the FI-AR module in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Using the extracted invoice number, it fetches the relevant receivable items. This information is automatically linked to the case, where agents can review and validate it.

5. Create Dispute in SAP S/4HANA

From the case details page, the service agent can create a dispute in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with a single click. The dispute case references the correct invoice, associates the appropriate dispute reason and amount, and links it to the relevant customer master data.

 

6. Case Tracking & Resolution

Through ESM, both internal teams and customers can track the progress of the dispute. Notifications, escalations, and collaboration features ensure timely resolution.

Business Value of SAP S/4HANA + ESM Integration

  • Faster Dispute Resolution: Reduces cycle time by eliminating manual handoffs.
  • Customer Satisfaction: Improves transparency and trust with real-time status visibility.
  • Operational Efficiency: Automates repetitive tasks, freeing teams to focus on high-value work.
  • Data-Driven Insights: Helps organizations identify recurring issues and fix root cause

Conclusion

Integrating SAP S/4HANA Dispute Management with ESM bridges the gap between finance operations and customer-facing services. It transforms dispute resolution from a siloed, manual process into a collaborative, automated, and transparent workflow. For organizations looking to enhance customer experience while safeguarding cash flow, this integration is not just a technical upgrade ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic move toward financial resilience and service excellence.

In short: Disputes don‚Äôt have to be disruptions ‚Äî with S/4HANA and ESM, they can become opportunities for service excellence.
